title: This music teacher is running the Boston Marathon for Parkinson’s research
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Owen Hughes Jr., 38, from White Plains, NY, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon to support Parkinson's research.
Hughes is an elementary music teacher aiming to raise funds for The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson’s Research.
The Boston Marathon will be Hughes' ninth marathon, highlighting his personal connection to the cause through his father's diagnosis.

title: Recent homes sales in Greater Boston (Feb. 18)
author: The Boston Globe
bullets: Abington's 840 Hancock St. Colonial sold for $705,000; 1,872 sq ft, 4 bedrooms, on 100,169 sq ft lot.
Acton's 405 Great Elm Way #405 condo townhouse sold for $502,500; 1,700 sq ft, 3 bedrooms, 3 baths.
Boston's 32 W Cedar St. row-middle home sold for $4.8 million; 4,013 sq ft, 5 bedrooms, 5 baths.

title: Cardi B appears to confirm Stefon Diggs split at L.A. concert
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Cardi B hinted at a split from Stefon Diggs during her L.A. concert on the 'Little Miss Drama' tour.
Breakup rumors emerged after Cardi B and Diggs unfollowed each other on Instagram post-Super Bowl.
Stefon Diggs faces battery and strangulation charges with a pre-trial hearing set for April 1.

title: UMass ordered to lift suspension for student who organized pro-Palestinian protest
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: UMass Amherst was ordered to lift Junior Kivlighan de Montebello's suspension after he organized a pro-Palestinian protest.
A Superior Court justice ruled Montebello's suspension likely violated his First Amendment rights to free speech.
The protest opposed RTX recruitment at a campus career fair, involving Montebello and about two dozen others.

title: Hanover police officer charged with motor vehicle homicide in fatal Brockton hit-and-run
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Hanover officer Thomas Hayes charged with vehicular homicide in Brockton hit-and-run; pleaded not guilty in court.
Victim Alfredo Alves, 23, was found unresponsive and later died; accident happened after Hayes visited a strip club.
Hayes, off duty at the time, allegedly drove aggressively; his SUV showed damage consistent with a collision.

title: Choosing a product that fixes foggy headlights
author: John Paul
bullets: Foggy headlights often result from worn protective coatings and can block up to 90% of light, says AAA studies.
Restoration products like Meguiar’s Keep Clear Headlight Coating can prevent re-fogging for up to a year.
Headlight maintenance is becoming regular preventive care, and restored headlights can outperform poor aftermarket replacements.

title: Man arrested in Fenway on child rape, human trafficking charges
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Talik Rashaun Garcia, 36, was arrested in Fenway on child rape and human trafficking charges after a police search.
Garcia faces charges including child rape, trafficking minors for sexual servitude, and possession of illicit child visual material.
Garcia was released on $5,000 cash bail with conditions, pleading not guilty to all charges in Boston Municipal Court.

title: Man charged with motor vehicle homicide in Pittsfield hit and run that saw victim dragged 4 miles, DA says
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: William Gross, 65, charged with motor vehicle homicide after hitting and killing 69-year-old William Colbert in Pittsfield.
Colbert was dragged four miles after being struck at Linden Street/Francis Avenue intersection on February 10.
Gross arrested without incident and scheduled for arraignment Wednesday in Central Berkshire District Court.

title: Mass. RMV lottery opens for 250th anniversary license plates. Here’s how to apply.
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Massachusetts RMV offers lottery for 1,000 commemorative license plates celebrating the state's 250th anniversary.
The lottery is open February 16 to April 17, 2026, with winners announced in early May.
Applicants must have valid vehicle registration, with winners paying a $60 registration and $40 specialty plate fee.

title: Massachusetts becomes first state to use ChatGPT in the executive branch, drawing criticism
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts is the first state to implement ChatGPT in the executive branch, impacting nearly 40,000 state employees.
AI assistant will be phased in starting with the Executive Office of Technology Services and Security; training programs offered.
Some state workers and NAGE express concerns about job impact and rushed implementation, citing security and privacy issues.
